confession.devil_appearance: appeared as a young boy, later as a black man or 'tronc de saulce' (willow trunk)
confession.seduction_date: at age 9 or 10, approximately 70 years before trial
confession.seduction_context: Went out of house in morning to pee, saw a young boy near her, had 'une mauvaise pensée, qu'elle se donnait volontiers a luy, pourvenu toutesfois qu'elle ne mourut jamais' - wished to give herself to him provided she would never die
powder_types: unspecified powders given 3 years before execution

testimony.quarrel_subject: Her son Claudon called Jeannotte a witch; she took him to court at Blamont
Mother accused Jenotte of taking her jewels
testimony.threat_quote: tu as un beau mary mais tu ne le garderas guere (you have a handsome husband but you won't keep him long)

harms_alleged.target: Demenge Mesoillin (first husband of witness's mother)

testimony.quarrel_subject: Military service exemption - Michiel Jean Thiebault was exempted, Colas Toussaint (accused's son) sent in his place
testimony.threat_quote: que ledit Michiel ne seroit empesché de mettre ses biens dedans (Michiel would not be prevented from bringing in his goods)

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: at harvest time, within a month

testimony.quarrel_subject: Military service exemption - his brother Michiel was sent
Collecting levy of 3 gros per conduit after passage of Bouillon's army; Jenotte complained there should have been a worthy man to collect it
testimony.threat_quote: ne sera, et les gros et grosses de Blamont nous garderont (it won't happen, and the big people of Blamont will protect us)

testimony.quarrel_subject: He and Demenge Marchal took pears from her garden
Took pears from her garden using a flail
Military service dispute involving her brother Michiel Jean Thiebault

testimony.threat_quote: elle ne mouroit pas mais qu'elle auroit du beau mal assé (she won't die but she will have plenty of sickness)

harms_alleged.target: Zabey femme Demenge le Grand Colas

witnesses.name: Zabel veuve Vaultrin Jobard
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: sister-in-law (accused married her brother Claudon Toussaint)

testimony.quarrel_subject: Multiple quarrels; called witch at church 15 years earlier

harms_alleged.target: multiple horses belonging to her husband Vaultrin Jobard

testimony.quarrel_subject: Dispute over ownership of a sheep
testimony.threat_quote: Gardez la bien, vous n'en feres guiere proffict (Keep it well, you won't profit much from it)

testimony.quarrel_subject: Dispute over missing sheep during mother's widowhood

witnesses.name: Zabel femme Demenge Grand Colas (dit le Parmentier)

testimony.quarrel_subject: Her seven-year-old son Colas found and ate an apple by Jeannotte's tree
testimony.threat_quote: qu'elle avoit la Caquet bien hault, mais que possible dans bien peu de temps, il luy seroit bien ravallé (she had her chatter very high, but possibly in a very short time, it would be brought down)

testimony.quarrel_subject: His son took apple from Jeannotte's tree

witnesses.name: Thoussainct Thirion
witnesses.relationship_to_accused: nephew by marriage (his father's wife was sister to Jeannotte's husband)

testimony.quarrel_subject: Dispute over inheritance and also animals straying into meadow
Quarrel between Jenotte and Claudon son of Demenge Jacquenin over wood
testimony.threat_quote: Qu'il s'en repentiroit et s'en donroit garde (He would regret it and would take care)

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: became sick and swollen, then died
after dispute over gages taken as maire

testimony.threat_quote: Nyon, bedey, nyon, je ne luy ay pas donné, et qu'il n'en craigne pas (No, indeed, no, I did not give it to him, and he need not fear)

witnesses.name: Jennon femme à Colas Jean Mongeot

testimony.quarrel_subject: Accused her younger sister Allison of stealing 'une fillée' during washing
testimony.threat_quote: Ces grandes oyseuses cy, il fault sentir sy elles sont grandes (These big idlers here, one must feel if they are big)

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: sick for more than 20 weeks before dying

timeline.subject: Jeannotte Toussaint
timeline.details: Procureur fiscal of Comté de Blamont reports receiving information about Jeannotte using dog's head with superstitious ceremonies to heal livestock

timeline.subject: Jeannotte Toussaint
timeline.details: First interrogation about the dog's head and its use

timeline.subject: Jeannotte Toussaint
timeline.details: Procureur Fiscal orders depositions to be taken, writes of 'grands abus et superstitions'

timeline.subject: Jeannotte Toussaint
timeline.details: Procureur fiscal asks for further interrogation

timeline.subject: Jeannotte Toussaint
timeline.details: Second interrogation, admits some quarrels but denies threats

timeline.subject: Jeannotte Toussaint
timeline.details: Voluntary statement - brought from prison believing she was ready to confess, makes partial admissions

timeline.subject: Jeannotte Toussaint
timeline.details: Procureur fiscal asks for question extraordinaire

timeline.subject: Jeannotte Toussaint
timeline.details: Interrogation under torture - thumbscrews, rack, shown strappado; confesses to witchcraft

timeline.subject: Jeannotte Toussaint
timeline.details: Procureur fiscal asks for death sentence 'a terreur et exemple d'autres'

timeline.subject: Jeannotte Toussaint
timeline.details: Change de Nancy approves death sentence

methods: strappado (shown but not applied - confessed when shown)
torture.requesting_official: Procureur fiscal of Comté de Blamont

accomplices_named.name: Menegou (devil's name, also appeared as young man)
accomplices_named.context: Named as her devil/master who told her to go to 'rondiat'

accomplices_named.name: Margueritte veuve Demenge Vaultrin (alias la Jobarde)
accomplices_named.context: Accused of telling Jeannotte about being thrown to ground by devil; suspected of making horse sick which recovered after she visited it

prior_accusations.accuser_name: Claudon (son of Margueritte veuve Demenge Jacquemin)
prior_accusations.context: Called her witch 7 years before trial; she took him to court at Blamont; they were reconciled

notable_quotes.speaker: Jeannotte Toussaint (to mother of Germain Claudin)
notable_quotes.french: tu as un beau mary mais tu ne le garderas guere
notable_quotes.english: you have a handsome husband but you won't keep him long
notable_quotes.context: Threat after quarrel about stolen jewels; husband fell from horse and died soon after

notable_quotes.speaker: Jeannotte Toussaint (to Didier Pierson about Michiel Jean Thiebault)
notable_quotes.french: que ledit Michiel ne seroit empesché de mettre ses biens dedans
notable_quotes.english: that Michiel would not be prevented from bringing in his goods
notable_quotes.context: After dispute over military service; Michiel became ill at harvest time and died within a month

notable_quotes.speaker: Jeannotte Toussaint (to Demenge Colbay)
notable_quotes.french: ne sera, et les gros et grosses de Blamont nous garderont
notable_quotes.english: it won't happen, and the big people of Blamont will protect us
notable_quotes.context: Response when he called her witch after tax collection dispute

notable_quotes.speaker: Claude Martin's father (about sheep)
notable_quotes.french: Gardez la bien, vous n'en feres guiere proffict
notable_quotes.english: Keep it well, you won't profit much from it
notable_quotes.context: After dispute over ownership of sheep; it died next day

notable_quotes.speaker: Jeannotte Toussaint (to Meline about Zabey's illness)
notable_quotes.french: elle ne mouroit pas mais qu'elle auroit du beau mal assé
notable_quotes.english: she won't die but she will have plenty of sickness
notable_quotes.context: Prediction about Zabey's illness after her son stole pears

notable_quotes.speaker: Jeannotte Toussaint (to Zabel femme Demenge Grand Colas)
notable_quotes.french: qu'elle avoit la Caquet bien hault, mais que possible dans bien peu de temps, il luy seroit bien ravallé
notable_quotes.english: she had her chatter very high, but possibly in a very short time, it would be brought down
notable_quotes.context: Threat during quarrel over son eating apple; witness became ill within two weeks

notable_quotes.speaker: Allison (dying sister of witness 26)
notable_quotes.french: la genoxe qui m'a donné ce mal Icy ne me veult pas laisser mourir
notable_quotes.english: the witch who gave me this illness doesn't want to let me die
notable_quotes.context: Said at height of her sickness after Jeannotte pinched her thigh

notable_quotes.speaker: Jeannotte Toussaint (at spinning gathering about Allison)
notable_quotes.context: Said smiling when women were lamenting Allison's condition; she died with great languishing some days later

notable_quotes.speaker: Estienne Counot (reporting threat to Claudon)
notable_quotes.french: Qu'il s'en repentiroit et s'en donroit garde
notable_quotes.english: He would regret it and would take care
notable_quotes.context: After quarrel over wood; Claudon became sick and swollen, then died

notable_quotes.speaker: Jeannotte Toussaint (about Thoussainct Thirion's illness)
notable_quotes.french: Nyon, bedey, nyon, je ne luy ay pas donné, et qu'il n'en craigne pas
notable_quotes.english: No, indeed, no, I did not give it to him, and he need not fear
notable_quotes.context: When asked if she had caused Thoussainct Thirion's illness

notable_quotes.speaker: Jeannotte Toussaint (about dog's head healing)
notable_quotes.french: qu'aucuns s'en sont bien porté, et les aultres non, ainsi qu'il a pleu a Dieu
notable_quotes.english: some have done well from it, and others not, as it pleased God
notable_quotes.context: Explaining that the dog's head healing sometimes worked and sometimes didn't

notable_quotes.speaker: Jeannotte Toussaint (at age 9 or 10)
notable_quotes.french: une mauvaise pensée, qu'elle se donnait volontiers a luy, pourvenu toutesfois qu'elle ne mourut jamais
notable_quotes.english: an evil thought, that she would willingly give herself to him, provided however that she would never die
notable_quotes.context: First seduction narrative - seeing a young boy when going out to pee

economic_context.details: Disputes over inheritance of family property between Jeannotte and relatives (Thirion Florentin family). Also multiple disputes over animals straying into gardens and fields, with fines and pledges taken. Accused had used dog's head for healing livestock for 30+ years, suggesting she may have received payment or goods for this service. Property valued at 35 francs when confiscated.

harms_catalog.harm_description: fatal illness lasting a year, became emaciated although ate normally
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Claudon called her witch, she took him to court at Blamont, they were reconciled

harms_catalog.harm_description: death of horse
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: horse strayed into her garden

harms_catalog.harm_description: fell from horse and died of injuries
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: mother accused Jenotte of taking her jewels

harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: at harvest time, within a month

harms_catalog.victim_relationship_to_witness: companion of witness 8, self as witness 9

harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: he and Jean Persin took pears from her garden
harms_catalog.method_alleged: poisoned/bewitched pear; later cured by grape sent by accused

harms_catalog.harm_description: detellé de tout par deux a trois fois par la mort de tous ses Chevaulx - lost all horses 2-3 times, very fine and valuable horses
harms_catalog.economic_value: tres beaux et bons - voir des plus vaillans qui fussent lors audit Leintrey

harms_catalog.method_alleged: witchcraft after threat; possibly cured during Jeannotte's visits by 'quelque subtil moyen'

harms_catalog.victim_relationship_to_witness: self as witness 22, husband to witness 23
harms_catalog.harm_description: became ill, in bed for eight days, had to confess; cured after Jeannotte brought pears

harms_catalog.method_alleged: witchcraft; cured by gift of pears

harms_catalog.harm_description: painful 'enflure' (swelling) between toes, cured when removed something like arquebus powder
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: none - went to well barefoot, asked to collect plums

harms_catalog.harm_description: one leg became shorter than the other, could only move with difficulty on a stick

harms_catalog.harm_description: death of horse

material_culture.context: Used for healing livestock with swelling; kept for 30+ years; borrowed by neighbors; anointed with pig grease (male or female); considered superstitious by authorities
Used to anoint dog's head before rubbing on swollen livestock
Multiple incidents involving pears: stolen from garden, given as cure/gift; sent grape as remedy
Sent to Demenge Marchal; he recovered after eating it
Seven-year-old son found and ate apple by Jeannotte's tree, precipitating quarrel
Used by Demenge Marchal to get pears from tree
Used to make noise during storm - local custom
Thrown at Margueritte femme Demenge Brouard during quarrel, felling her
Accused of stealing jewels from neighbor
Taken as pledge so animals could be fined for straying into meadow
Husband playing near church; she knocked them down in anger
Husband sent cart to fetch her from Rey for wedding
Given by her master 3 years before execution; used to cause harm
Used to kill calf of Jean Mongeot
Given by master to harm Zabey Parmentier; also remedy given twisted in paper
Something like this removed from swollen foot to cure it
Accused Allison of stealing during washing; found at bottom of cauldron
Supposedly stolen from washing by Allison
Both families had sheep with different marks; dispute over ownership
Amount Claudon was to pay Jeannotte after court reconciliation
Value of accused's goods when sold/confiscated
Fine wanted for straying animals
Tax levy being collected after passage of Bouillon's army
Jennon could only move with difficulty on a stick due to leg condition

spatial_references.context: Primary location of trial, residence of accused and most witnesses
Birthplace of accused; where she lived with parents until age 14
Seat of court, location of Procureur Fiscal; where accused taken legal action
Where accused worked for Chapelain Hanneze for 1 year
Where accused worked for Claudon du Chattel for 2 years
Location of mill where accused worked for Jan Mulnier for 1 year
Gagnage (farm/estate) where accused married her mistress's brother
Location of curé who refused to bless Margueritte's dog head
Location of Change de Nancy (appellate court) that approved torture and death sentence
Where troops were being sent during wars; where Michiel Jean Thiebault had served before
Where horses were guarded; where devil appeared; where accused was chased after quarrel
Where quarrel occurred leaving church; where husband played quilles nearby
Where Thoussainct Thirion went barefoot and got swollen foot
Where sabbat was held with masked women dancing and singing
Where horse strayed; where pears and apples were stolen from trees
Where animals strayed, precipitating dispute over fines
Route of Bouillon's army; paths between houses and church
Where Jeannotte was held; where devil visited her

historical_context.military_details: Multiple references to military activity: Captain Besancon (prévôt of Blamont) and lieutenant Henry Hannost raising troops to send into Germany during 'previous wars'; passage of Bouillon's army through region; tax levy of 3 gros per conduit collected after army passage; Michiel Jean Thiebault had already served in Germany once; servant from 'Allemagne' mentioned
weather_events: storm (16 years before trial - witness saw accused making strange signs during storm while bells were being rung)
economic_hardship_indicators: disputes over small amounts of money and food (pears, apples)
taking coats as pledges for fines
concern over inheritance if husband died childless
multiple references to livestock deaths causing economic losses
Zabey Parmentier described as poor with 5 or 6 children
religious_calendar_references: curé called to administer last rites

officials_named.name: Procureur fiscal of Comté de Blamont

prior_legal_disputes.description: Claudon son of Demenge Jacquemin called her witch; she took him to court at Blamont 7 years before trial
prior_legal_disputes.outcome: Reconciled by M Hanné (Henry Hannot, lieutenant of prévôt); Claudon to pay her 2 francs

prior_legal_disputes.description: Struck Margueritte femme Demenge Brouard with stone after being called witch at church 15 years earlier
prior_legal_disputes.outcome: Husband had to pledge on her behalf that she would not flee

prior_legal_disputes.description: Dispute over 'gages' (pledges/fines) taken by Didier Breton in his capacity as maire

legal_context.redress_outcome: Won case against Claudon with reconciliation and 2 franc payment, but he died shortly after
legal_context.imprisonment_conditions: Devil/incubus visited her in prison; brought from prison multiple times for interrogation

hearsay_chains.content: heard mother accuse Jeannotte of causing death of first husband Demenge Mesoillin
discovered they suspected Jenotte as result of quarrel over son stealing pears
had heard reports of bad reputation for some years
heard story that when cart sent to fetch accused for wedding, some said fire should be put under it
heard carpenters calling her witch more than 20 years earlier
conversation between Jenotte and his sister was reported to him by two boys
father blamed Jenotte for loss of various beasts
knew her reputation; people said if husband died childless, property would go to Jenotte's family
witnessed quarrel but reported death of Claudon
father-in-law thought she killed his horse

hearsay_chains.reporter: Jennon femme à Colas Jean Mongeot (witness 26)
hearsay_chains.content: had been reported that Jenotte said at spinning 'elle ne moeurut pas encore' about dying Allison

emotional_state_notes: firmly denied threats while maintaining innocence
started to 'varyer et desnyer tout son dire' - vary and deny all her statements after partial confession
appeared not to suffer from first tortures (thumbscrews and rack)
began to confess when shown strappado (before it was applied)

reproaches_to_witnesses.objection: Agreed her son suffered from 'mal St. Marcou' but hadn't died from this (contradicting death claim)
Absolutely denied having spoken of 'gros et grosses de Blamont'
Said it was Marguerite's husband she had called witch, not Marguerite; said she threw only a small stone at back and Marguerite 'se laissa aussy tost tomber' (let herself fall) and was hardly ill
On arrest said to sergent that there were people in Leintrey worse than her, and they were cause of her being taken to Blamont. Said those who complained against her were thieves.

third_parties.name: Demenge Mesoillin

third_parties.name: Thirion Florentin (deceased)

third_parties.name: Vaultrin Jobard (deceased)
third_parties.context: Lost all his horses 2-3 times; suspected Jenotte's witchcraft; witnessed called him 'seorque' (male witch)

third_parties.name: Jean Bon Claude
third_parties.context: Had been banished from Leintrey; seen at sabbat riding horse among great assembly dancing

third_parties.name: Sebille femme Jean Pierson
third_parties.context: Seen at sabbat according to confession under torture

third_parties.name: Jean Mongeot
third_parties.context: His calf was killed in revenge for fining accused's son's horses, according to confession

third_parties.name: Colas (seven-year-old son)
third_parties.context: Found and ate apple by Jeannotte's tree, precipitating major quarrel

third_parties.name: daughter (14 years old)
third_parties.context: Called 'Borne le diable' by Jeannotte; responded by calling her 'vieille genoxe' (old witch)

third_parties.name: granddaughter of Jeannotte's son Claudon
third_parties.context: Slept in bed with accused 3.5 years before trial when devil appeared as dead husband

extraction_metadata.notes: Very detailed trial record with extensive witness testimony (26 witnesses), clear timeline, confession under torture, and rich social context. Notable for: (1) initial superstition charge regarding dog's head used for folk healing, (2) transformation into full witchcraft trial, (3) extensive reputation testimony spanning 40 years, (4) multiple healing incidents where accused both caused and cured illnesses (especially with food gifts), (5) complex family relationships including sister-in-law witness, (6) economic disputes over livestock, inheritance, and military service exemptions, (7) accused sought legal redress herself 7 years earlier, (8) confession only after torture (resistant to thumbscrews and rack, confessed when shown strappado), (9) very elderly accused (80+ years old) with long community presence, (10) detailed material culture around folk healing practices.
